name: JSON
title: JSON

children.text: process data or create new content in JSON format.
You do not need to establish a connection to use the JSON app.
You can use the following modules to build your
Converts the multiple output bundles to a single bundle.
You need to attach this aggregator module to the source module whose output you want to convert to a single module; for example, the Parse JSON modules give the output in multiple bundles.
After selecting the source module, select the data structure, and the remaining fields are populated from the source module.
and run it. The output is only one bundle.
Converts the given JSON data to XML format.
This module helps you create JSON. The fields in this module depends on your data structure.
The data structure describes how the JSON data is organized and enables mapping individual JSON items to other modules in your
Select the data structure and enter the field details to create JSON. The data provided in the module returns in the JSON format in the output.
The data structure describes how the JSON data is organized and enables mapping individual JSON items to other modules in your
. If you don't provide the Data structure, you may manually run the module and
will build the structure from the provided JSON:
Do not yet connect the modules that follow. Since
doesn't know the structure of the JSON data, it will not be possible to map data from the
module to other modules in your
module will identify the JSON structure from your provided JSON.
You can now connect the modules that follow. The items from the
module will now be available for mapping.
JSON string field can contain a collection.
In which case, the output will be a single bundle containing the items of the collection:
Or it can contain an array.
In which case the output will be a series of bundles, each bundle containing one array's item.
Simulate module output using Parse JSON
allows you to use the data from the existing module to test your
. You can run this operation using the
Run the module whose output data you want to copy using the
Click the resulting output above the module.
A window containing the original module's output bundles in JSON format pops up.
Copy the window's content and click
module after the original module, open its configuration, and paste the copied JSON data in Step 4 into the
Unlink the original module from the
Do not delete the original module.
Execute the mock-up JSON module and use its output instead of the original module's output in your
Once you are done with the testing, change the mapping from the mock-up module to the original module across the whole
Put the original module back before the mock-up JSON module and remove the JSON module.
section, it is not necessary to fill the
field unless you do not want to remap all values from the original module in the whole
Let us assume that the data records you wish to transform to JSON format are in a Google spreadsheet. Here is the procedure on how to transform the data records to JSON format:
to get the data. Set up the module to retrieve rows from your Google spreadsheet and set the
to a small number but larger than one for testing purposes (e.g., three). Run the
module (right-click it and choose "Run this module only") and verify its output.
module. In the module's setup, choose the
field. Leave the other fields as they are for the moment.
module. The module's setup requires a data structure that describes the JSON format. Click the
button to open the Data structure setup. The easiest way to create this Data structure is to generate it automatically from a JSON sample. Click the Generator button and paste your JSON sample to the
in the Data structure setup should now contain the generated structure.
Change the name of your Data structure to something more specific (e.g., "Books") and click
. A field corresponding to the root array attribute should appear mappable in the
button next to the field and map the
module's field corresponding to the root array attribute. Map items output from the
module should output the correct JSON format. Open the setup of the

module and increase the Maximum number of returned rows number to be larger than the number of rows in your spreadsheet to process all the data. The resulting JSON can then be used as a body of an HTTP request, returned as a Webhook's response, etc.

customCSS:
<style>
@media print {
  html, body {
    overflow-x: visible;
  }
}
#tally-widget-button {
  position: fixed !important;
  background-color: #FFFFFF;
  display: none;
  visibility: visible !important;
  opacity: 1 !important;
  color: #0C121D;
  border: 2px solid #0C121D;
  border-radius: 4px;
  align-items: center;
  justify-content: center;
  font-size: 14px;
  font-weight: 600;
  font-family: 'Inter';
  text-align: center;
  box-shadow: 0 4px 6px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2);
  cursor: pointer;
  z-index: 999999 !important;
  -webkit-tap-highlight-color: transparent;
  outline: none;
  touch-action: manipulation;
  pointer-events: auto;
  transform: translate3d(0, 0, 0);
}
.button-text {
  display: inline-block;
  margin-right: 8px;
}
.button-text::before {
  content: attr(data-text);
}
#tally-widget-popup {
  position: fixed;
  background-color: white;
  display: none;
  border-radius: 12px;
  box-shadow: 0 10px 20px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.4);
  z-index: 999999;
  overflow: hidden;
  border: 0px solid #0C121D;
  padding-top: 30px;
}
#tally-widget-close {
  position: absolute;
  top: 10px;
  right: 10px;
  background: none;
  border: none;
  font-size: 36px;
  font-weight: bold;
  padding: 8px;
  cursor: pointer;
  color: #0C121D;
}

  .ab-plugin-wrapper .ab-link-block-item .ab-link {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
    font-family: 'Inter' !important;
  }

  .dark .ab-plugin-wrapper .ab-link-block-item .ab-link {
    color: #F6F6F6 !important;
  }
  
  #main-column > div > div > div.flex.flex-1.w-full.justify-center.pb-0 > div > div.flex.items-center.pl-0.pr-2.mb-5.xl\:-mt-1\.5 > div > div > div > div:nth-child(1) > div.flex.pr-2.text-gray-500.items-center {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  a.ab-tree-navigation-link-active span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  .ab-public-space-links-wrap .ab-public-space-link:first-of-type {
    border-color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  .ab-toc-item-active a{
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  #main-column .text-ab-blue-500 span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  
  #main-column .text-ab-blue-500 {
    text-decoration-color: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  .ab-nav-left:hover > svg,
  .ab-nav-left:hover .text-gray-300,
  .ab-nav-left:hover .ab-nav-left-text {
     color: #7302D5 !important;
     stroke: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  .ab-nav-right:hover > svg,
  .ab-nav-right:hover .text-gray-300,
  .ab-nav-right:hover .ab-nav-right-text {
     color: #7302D5 !important;
     stroke: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  
#tally-inline-popup {
  position: fixed;
  display: none;
  z-index: 999999;
  width: min(420px, 90vw);
  height: min(550px, 80vh);
  background: #fff;
  color: #0c121d;
  border: 1px solid rgba(0,0,0,0.08);
  border-radius: 12px;
  box-shadow: 0 12px 28px rgba(0,0,0,0.22), 0 2px 6px rgba(0,0,0,0.12);
  overflow: hidden;
  padding: 5px;
}

#tally-inline-popup iframe {
  width: 100%;
  height: 100%;
  border: 0;
  display: block;
  border-radius: 8px;
}

#tally-inline-popup .tip-close {
  position: absolute;
  top: 6px;
  right: 8px;
  width: 32px;
  height: 32px;
  line-height: 28px;
  font-size: 22px;
  text-align: center;
  background: rgba(255,255,255,0.85);
  border: 1px solid rgba(0,0,0,0.06);
  border-radius: 8px;
  cursor: pointer;
}

#main-column a[data-form-url],
#main-column a[data-tally-url] {
  color: #7302D5 !important;
  text-decoration: underline;
  text-underline-offset: 2px;
  text-decoration-thickness: 1.5px;
  font-weight: 600;
}

@media (max-width: 640px) {
  #tally-inline-popup {
    width: min(360px, 94vw);
    height: min(500px, 80vh);
  }
}

#main-column .ab-cta-button a.ab-cta-button {
  background-color: #7302D5;
}

/* Titles in purple */
.ab-link-blocks-wrapper .ab-link-block-item.ab-docs-card-mode .ab-link-block-content-wrap .font-bold {
  color: #7302D5 !important;
}

.ab-tree-navigation-link-active span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
}

</style>

reusableContentVariables.name: string
reusableContentVariables.description: a list or sequence of characters (like letters, numbers, and symbols) used to represent text in a computer programming.

reusableContentVariables.name: Operations
reusableContentVariables.description: An operation is a single module run to process data or check for new data.

reusableContentVariables.name: Credits
reusableContentVariables.description: Credits (formerly operations) are the currency for running scenarios.

reusableContentVariables.name: Route
reusableContentVariables.description: A route is a path that data can flow through in a scenario, visualized as the dotted lines between modules.
